Posts.Title: Today's posts in breast cancer and in radiotherapy.

Posts.Content: Sorry London Lass, my last post seemed to have some other stuff about me on it.  Not intended.
Posts.Title: Not sure if any of you knew Nesslay

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear that sad news London Lass.  Hang in there, here is a huge ((((((((((((hug)))))))))) from me. Love Linda
Posts.Title: Not sure if any of you knew Nesslay

Posts.Content: Hi Fiddlercrab, I think it is great your unit want to do something for younger women.  I am not one of them (67) but I got talking to a couple of younger women, aged 38 and 45, whilst waiting in breast care clinic and they said they had been pleasantly surprised that they were treated as individuals and given lots of information about local groups and also the same very comprehensive folder that I was given, which is provided by Breast cancer Care and is very helpful.  They were also shown the extensive Macmillan leaflet rack which had all sorts of booklets for all ages in it for you take home whichever ones you felt were relevant.  So if my small hospital can do it why can't others? Good luck on your journey.
Posts.Title: Feedback for BCN

Posts.Content: What about KC?  Knockerless chest! Hugs Linda
Posts.Title: What do you call yours?

Posts.Content: Thank you so much. Really helpful.   No I am lucky I don't need chemotherapy or Herceptin.  Hope all is going well for you? Lindylou49
Posts.Title: Endocrine therapy

Posts.Content: Had op (wide angle excision) on December 22nd , just had pathology report which says the cancer was ER8, PR8, and HER2 negative.  I thought endocrine therapy was just for HER POSITIVE results.  Can anyone explain why I am being offered it if my cancer was HER negative?
Posts.Title: Endocrine therapy

Posts.Content: Hi KitKat I am also large breasted but bought some of those soft crop tops to wear at night, no fastenings, no lace just stretchy.  I start my radiotherapy on 6th March and will try these if a bra is too painful. Only thing I would say is, buy a size larger than your normal bra size,  No uplift but does stop the swing! And you feel as though you have SOME support. Very gentle hugs to you.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy burns & blisters

Posts.Content: Well done Flossie! I have downloaded an app to my phone which measures how many active minutes you walk each day as my Physio said "walking is good for you but you should be out of breath for at least 10 minutes every day to gain benefit from it". I really don't agree!  I think just walking, especially in beautiful places, is good for mind, body and soul.  However, I thought it couldn't hurt to walk a bit quicker for just 10 minutes a day, but I live in a village and when you stop to say hello and have a quick chat with all the dog walkers etc, it doesn't clock it as 10 minutes because you stopped!   I refuse to be a slave to technology and shall enjoy my walks and if I manage the 10 minutes well and good, if not, doesn't matter.  Do you agree? Wish I could get my photos on here...... Hugs Linda x
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Dee, So sorry to hear about your cording.  I had it too, but under my arm to just above the elbow.  Strangely enough it never went any further.  I saw a physio who massaged the cord, ouch, and showed me how to do it in between weekly appointments, she said to do it firmly even if it hurts, every night before you go to bed, and I popped it once myself, and then she popped it twice more and eventually it went on it's own.  I didn't have lymphodoema though so not sure if that makes  difference. Hope you get it sorted soon.  Big (((((((hugs))))))) Linda
Posts.Title: Cording 15 months after surgery!

Posts.Content: What  a lovely idea Violetsniff! Your name always reminds me of a dearly loved Great Aunt who always wore ashes of violets perfume.  She was a great knitter too.  Not surprising really as she was one of the first female buyers in the wool department at DH Evans in Oxford Street in London.  She was also a suffragette! Big hugs to all and hope you all get out for a walk tomorrow. Linda xx

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Seaspirit, I also think it is rubbish, but keep watching in case it gets better! Such a shame because I really liked the first series......... Linda x
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Ronstar I have just caught up with this thread again as my phone doesn't seem to like the new way of working! Of course you have changed.  We all have; it puts things into perspective and I know I can't be bothered with people who are upsetting me any more.  I have some great friends who have walked alongside me on this journey and they are the ones that I cherish.  Their kindness and generosity have kept me going (rather like all the lovely people on this thread!). The others I have not fallen out with, but instead of me always arranging things and keeping in touch, I have left it up to them to do so, and if that means we drift apart, then so be it. I was once told that "friends are sent to you, sometimes for a reason and sometimes for a season". Perhaps that is true. As to the mammogram.  I was given some good advice by the radiographer who I was to see, she said, take a strong painkiller 1/2 hour before your mammogram and it will make the world of difference, and it did! Lots of hugs Linda
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Well done LesleyHelen! You are an inspiration! I love following all the posts on here and it has perked me up no end when I have felt down and unable to do much walking. Now all I need to do is work out how to download the pictures from my walks from my iphone!  Big hugs to all. Linda

Posts.Content: Did you sit in the front and pretend you were driving? I think he would be very embarrassed about it now as he is 14 and considers himself a cool Londoner. Hugs Linda

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Happybird I am so sorry for you and your partner. Life can be a real bummer sometimes.  Please look after yourself as well as your partner.Don't neglect yourself; I am sure you have recovered and are here for a purpose and I hope you have a a beautiful wedding, I don't mean all the trimmings etc, but beautiful because it is the two of you.  Please keep posting and let us provide you with a measure of comfort at such a sad time. Love and hugs to you both. Linda x

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Eden Welcome to the site.  None of us wanted to be in this situation but this place is wonderful.  I have been here for 8 months and don't know what I would have done without it!  There is always someone who understands what you are experiencing and has some good advice and, perhaps as importantly, someone who is there to give you a hug (figuratively speaking)  and a non judgemental ear. So here is your first hug (((((((hug))))))).  Linda
Posts.Title: Hello, I am new, anyone there?

Posts.Content: Glad radiotherapy made your seroma shrink JeanieB. Hope it goes on shrinking!   I also have one which seems to have shrunk with radiotherapy, but I have a tender area under my arm (not in my armpit) which feels as though it is fluid filled.  Can you develop a seroma this long after surgery, does anyone know?  I had wide angle excision in December 2016 and finished 3 weeks of rt on 30th March.  Spoke to breast care nurse who didn't know!
Posts.Title: Seroma update

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for the reply Lynn.  I am going for physio next week for the cording under my arm so will ask the Physio what she thinks.  See the Oncologist the week after so see if Physio thinks it can wait til then.  And yes, I am still doing my exercises! Perhaps not as conscientious as you though as I only do them twice a day! So glad I joined this site. Linda xx
Posts.Title: Seroma update

Posts.Content: Hi Gallus I am 18 months post op and just over a year post radiotherapy.  I am also on Anastrazole. I also joined Slimming World as my weight had ballooned from 11 stone 5 to 14 stone. I saw the Dietician at the hospital where I had radiotherapy who gave me a diet plan to follow of 2000 healthy calories a day and told me to follow it for a month.  This I did and put on half a stone!  She  said if I had been dieting on and off for a long time, my body was resistant to change! Not helpful I thought, but maybe she is right. Anyway I joined Slimming World 2 months ago and have lost 8 lbs, not great I thought, just 1 lb a week.  Spoke to someone online at Slimming World who said to cut my portion size a bit, because although it is healthy eating, you do not have to watch how much you eat of "free foods" so I am going to try this and will see how I go. I should say, that like you I also exercise. It IS depressing, I agree but I am determined to lose this weight which basically just sits there around my middle!  I think Anastrazole doesn't help either but as I am on it for another 3.5 years at least I guess I shall just have to try a bit harder. Be kind to yourself though.  We have been through a lot but we will get where we are supposed to be eventually. Have you seen the "Walking back to Happiness" thread?  Always gives me a lift, even if I am just reading it and not walking as much as I would like. <<<<<<Virtual hugs>>>>>> Linda x
Posts.Title: Weight Issues

Posts.Content: Hi Flopsy I finished my radiotherapy 2 weeks ago and the scar tissue I had on one side of my boob has gone really hard and lumpy and looks bruised, also my inverted nipple on that side is now sticking out and MUCH darker than the other one!   I saw the Radiologist  last week, and she said the discolouration can last up to 18 months.  She also said that rads can stiffen tendons etc and scar tissue.  She said to massage it but at the moment it is too sore.  See the Oncologist in 2 weeks so will ask him then as well. the more opinions the better I think!So I suppose it is just different for us all. Writing down what you wan to say before you have an appointment is a good idea, otherwise you can get side tracked and forget what you wanted to say. Good luck with the Consultant. Linda
Posts.Title: Misshapen nipple after Rads - anyone else?

Posts.Content: Love it!  I was feeling down about a lot of things, now smiling.  Thank you. Linda

Posts.Title: Phew!

Posts.Content: Hi Rainbow Debs, Thanks for your reply. I had a Dexa scan before I started Letrozole and am osteopenic, not got osteoporosis yet! So on Vitamin D and Calcium supplement, but I think I will try a supplement for hair, can't do any harm except to my bank balance! Linda
Posts.Title: Letrozole -hair loss

Posts.Content: Thank you so much Hedgewitch, I will give it a go! Hugs Linda
Posts.Title: Letrozole -hair loss

Posts.Content: Hi Lavendergirl, I have been taking Letrozole since February this year and I have noticed that my hair is much thinner (wasn't thick in the first place!) and I hate to say this, but I think it is getting worse.  I have handfuls in my hairbrush and in the plughole when I wash it.  I did go to my GP but was told it was a small price to pay if it gave me a better chance of my cancer not coming back!!   I would be interested if anyone else has taken the hair and nail supplements I have seen in health food shops, and whether it has made a difference? Letrozole has a lot to answer for, even if you do get a brand that "suits" you; thinner hair, thinner skin and thinner bones....... Linda
Posts.Title: Letrozole -hair loss

Posts.Content: Hi Fran I know exactly what you are going through! I don't know if it would work for you, but after 11 months of Letrozole I felt I couldn't stand it any longer.  I spoke to the surgeon and he suggested Anastrozole.  I thought the terrible stiffness, joint pains, hot flushes, cold flushes (lizard moments!) and sweats would be the same as on Letrozole, but 2 months on I am stiff in the mornings or if I sit for too long, but the pain in my joints has gone!  He suggested I had acupuncture for the hot flushes and sweats as I didn't wan to take any MORE drugs.  I have had 7 sessions and my sweats have gone completely, and my hot flushes are reduced to feeling warm but not turning red and shiny!  I have another 7 sessions to go but am told that they shouldn't come back...  I was sceptical at first but am a complete convert now. Big hugs Linda
Posts.Title: Sweats awful

Posts.Content: Hi Lin Thank you for your reply.  Acupuncture is certainly working for me! Are you able to post a link to the acupuncture article?  I would like to read it if possible. Many thanks Linda
Posts.Title: Sweats awful
